title: Simon Willison's LLM predictions for 2026
description: Simon Willison shared his 1, 3, and 6 year predictions for AI and LLMs on the Oxide and Friends annual predictions podcast. The predictions cover the future trajectory of LLM development and their impact on software development.
author: Simon Willison

title: Replit CEO Amjad Masad: From 'terrorist sympathizer' to $3B AI valuation
description: Profile of Amjad Masad and Replit's journey to $3B valuation. Masad is quoted saying 'I must apologize to â€” absolutely nobody,' showing he's not afraid of Silicon Valley controversy. The article discusses how CEOs can now 'vibe code their own prototypes' and how product managers may be 'some of the best vibe coders.' Replit's AI platform enables internet-free coding and has become central to the vibe coding movement.
author: San Francisco Standard

title: LMArena lands $1.7B valuation four months after launch
description: TechCrunch reports that LMArena achieved a $1.7B valuation just four months after launching its product. The article mentions Claude Code, Anthropic's AI-powered coding tool, being made available to Allianz employees, with plans to build custom AI solutions. This indicates significant enterprise adoption of AI coding tools.
author: TechCrunch

title: Top 9 Large Language Models as of January 2026
description: Shakudo publishes a comprehensive overview of the top 9 LLMs making waves in the industry as of January 2026, covering the latest models and their capabilities for coding and other tasks.
author: Shakudo

title: AI Trends in 2026 Explained | Future of Artificial Intelligence
description: YouTube video covering how AI is evolving faster than ever, with 2026 marking a major turning point in how AI systems think, act, and integrate into various domains including software development.
author: Various YouTube Creators

title: Andrej Karpathy: 'I've never felt this much behind as a programmer'
description: Karpathy, former Tesla AI Director and OpenAI founding member, expresses feeling overwhelmed by AI-driven changes in programming. He describes the profession being 'dramatically refactored' with programmers contributing increasingly sparse bits between AI agents, subagents, prompts, contexts, memory, modes, permissions, tools, and plugins. He calls this a 'magnitude 9 earthquake' rocking the profession and urges developers to 'roll up your sleeves to not fall behind.'
author: Andrej Karpathy
